metadata.title: Effect of alkalis on iron-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts: Alkali-FeO<ce:inf loc=post>x</ce:inf> interaction, reduction, and catalytic performance

Effect of alkalis on iron-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts: Alkali-FeOx interaction, reduction, and catalytic performance Jifan Li a Xiaofan Cheng b Chenghua Zhang a ⁎ Qiang Chang a Jue Wang a Xiaoping Wang a Zhengang Lv a Wensheng Dong c Yong Yang a Yongwang Li a a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China b Shaanxi Coal and Chemical Industry Technology Development Centre Co., LTD, PR China Shaanxi Coal and Chemical Industry Technology Development Centre Co., LTD PR China c Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, PR China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU) MOE School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shaanxi Normal University Xi’an 710062 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Alkalis (Li, Na, K, Rb and Cs) promoted Fe/SiO2 catalysts were used to investigate the influences of alkalis on the alkali-FeOx interaction, reduction behavior, and catalytic performance of iron-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts. Laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Mössbauer effect spectroscopy (MES), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (in situ XPS) and in situ X-ray diffraction (in situ XRD) were employed to characterize the catalysts. It was found that alkalis had strong interactions with iron species in catalysts. In as-prepared catalysts, the FeO bonds are strengthened by alkalis, which consequently influenced the reduction of catalysts. Li and Na strongly restrained the reduction of all iron oxides in catalysts. K, Rb and Cs inhibited the initial reduction step (reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4), while improved the reduction of iron oxides to FeO and metallic iron. Besides, alkalis facilitated the carbonization of catalysts and the improvement increased with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. In FTS reactions, Li and Na decreased the FTS activity while K, Rb and Cs largely increased the FTS activity of iron catalysts. The selectivities to methane and alkane were decreased while those to olefin and heavier hydrocarbons were increased by alkalis. Keywords Alkalis Alkali-FeOx interaction Reduction Iron-based catalyst Fischer-Tropsch synthesis 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) as an important route for converting coal/natural gas to liquid fuels is considered as a promising and practical industrial solution for short-term petroleum alternatives and long-term liquid fuel productions from non-fossil carbon resources [1,2]. Iron-based catalysts are preferentially used in FTS processes due to their low costs, high FTS and WGS activities, flexible operation conditions [3]. The additions of promoters (K, Mg, Ca, Cu, Mn, Mo, and others) into iron-based catalysts are beneficial for facilitating the reduction or improving the activity and selectivity of catalysts [4]. Alkali metals, especially for potassium, are normally added to iron-based catalysts as chemical promoters [5]. They were reported to increase FTS activity [5], WGS activity [6], and olefins and long-chain hydrocarbon selectivities [7]. The positive effects on activity and selectivity are often explained in terms of the electropositivity of alkali promoters, which causes a charge transfer from alkali promoter to transition metal surface, thereby inhibiting H2 adsorption but enhancing CO adsorption and dissociation [8]. In practice, however, alkali promoters do not show a consensus in influencing the performance of iron-based catalysts in FTS reaction. Ngantsoue-Hoc et al. [9] studied the impacts of different alkali promoters on FTS performances of FeSi catalysts. They found that K was the best promoter, which increased the CO conversion rate at all conversion levels relative to the unprompted catalyst. Lighter alkali promoters (e.g., Li and Na) improved the CO conversion rate in the low to moderate conversion range; however, in the high conversion range, they were ineffective or even inhibited the CO conversion. For heavier alkali promoters (e.g., Rb and Cs), CO conversion rates were lower relative to the unprompted catalyst when they were added over the entire range of conversion. However, the dependency of alkali promotion on CO conversion level is not clear in principle. Besides, different alkalis also have different influences on the reduction and carburization behaviors of iron-based catalysts. Jiang et al. [10] investigated the effects of potassium on Fe-Mn catalysts by in situ diffuse reflectance FT-IR using NO, CO and CO+H2 as probes. Their results indicated that the potassium species tightly interacted with the surface iron species and promotes its reduction to form the fine metallic iron clusters. However, the investigation of Li et al. [11] revealed that the presence of potassium inhibited the reducibility of precipitated iron catalysts both with and without Cu in hydrogen due to a possible blockage of nucleation sites by potassium. Rankin and Bartholomew [12] found that the reduction extent of Fe/SiO2 catalyst in hydrogen decreased with increasing potassium content. Similar results were also obtained over Fe-Mn precipitated catalysts by Yang et al. [7]. Xiong, et al. [13] studied the effect of group I alkali metals on Fe/CNT catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. They found that Li modestly enhanced the reducibility of the catalyst whereas Na and K slightly inhibited its reduction. Ribeiro et al. [14] investigated the promotional impact of alkali metals (Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs) on the carburization rate of FeSi catalysts by X-ray absorption spectroscopy. They found that the carburization rate increased in the following order: unpromoted<Li<Na<K=Rb=Cs. Clearly, these discrepancies are partly resulted from the diversity of alkali metals and partly from the complicated interactions between alkali promoters and iron species in catalysts. However, the interactions are scarcely reported. In particular, the interactions between alkalis and iron oxides are extremely important, which would subsequently influence the activation of catalysts. In this perspective, it is worthy to study the effect of alkali promoters on reduction behaviors of iron-based catalysts. Alkali metals (Li, Na, K Rb and Cs) locate in the same group in the Periodic Table and have similar properties. Simultaneous, they have increased atomic radius and decreased electronegativities with increasing the atomic number. The variations in the atomic properties would have different influences on the reduction of iron-based catalysts. Therefore, studying the effects of alkali promoters on the reduction of iron catalysts can reveal the complicated interactions between alkalis and iron. The most commonly used method to study catalyst reducibility is temperature programmed reduction (TPR). However, many factors influence the positions of peaks during TPR, making the assignment of TPR peaks difficult. Suitable techniques to follow phase transformations accompanying the TPR process are needed. In the previous studies [15–17], X-ray diffraction (XRD), Mössbauer effect spectroscopy (MES), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) have been employed to analysis the phase evolution during the reduction process of iron-based catalysts. However, these techniques are ex-situ methods and the samples are usually passivated before characterization, which would be difficult to provide accurate information about the phase transformation of catalysts. Therefore, suitable in situ methods are urgently necessary to follow phase transformations of the catalyst bulk or surface accompanying the reduction process. In this work, in situ XRD was used to follow the bulk phase transformations during the TPR process. At the same time, in situ XPS technique was employed to study the surface species evolutions during reduction process. In the present study, a series of Fe/SiO2 catalysts with an alkali/iron atomic ratio of 2/100 were designed and prepared by a combination method of precipitation and spray-drying technology. The alkali-FeOx interaction, roles of alkalis in the reduction of catalyst bulk and surface, the phase evolution of catalysts after reduction and FTS reaction were fully characterized by multiple techniques, including N2 adsorption, laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), XPS, MES, H2-TPR, in situ XRD, and in situ XPS techniques. In addition, the FTS performances of catalysts were tested in a fixed-bed reactor and correlated with the characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared by the combination of co-precipitation and spray-drying technologies. In brief, a solution containing ferric nitrate and silica sol in the desired ratio (Si/Fe atomic ratio=5:100) was used in precipitation with NH4OH solution as precipitator at pH=8.5±0.3 and T=70°C. The precipitate was washed and filtered. Alkalis were subsequently added by wetness impregnation with an aqueous alkali nitrate to obtain an alkali/iron atomic ratio of 2:100. The mixture was re-slurried and spray-dried. The spray-dried powder was calcined at 500°C for 5h in a muffle furnace. The catalysts were denoted as FeSi, LiFeSi, NaFeSi, KFeSi, RbFeSi, and CsFeSi. 2.2 Catalyst treatments and characterizations The reduced catalyst samples used for TEM-EDS, and MES characterizations were prepared by reducing the fresh catalysts in a quartz tuble with H2 at 300°C, 0.10MPa, and 1000h−1 for 25h. After reduction, the catalysts for MES measurements were coated with paraffin to prevent oxidation. The samples for TEM measurement were passivated with 1%O2/99%N2 at room temperature. After FTS reaction, the used catalysts were passivated by a flow of 1%O2/99%N2 at room temperature and then collected for Raman, TEM and MES measurements. The BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of catalysts as prepared were obtained via nitrogen physisorption in ASAP 2420 equipment (Micromeritics, USA). Each sample was degassed under vacuum at 90°C for 1h and 350°C for 8h prior to the measurement. XRD patterns were obtained with a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray laboratory diffractometerusing Cu Kα radiation (γ=1.5406Å). The phase transformation during hydrogen temperature programmed reduction was conducted in an in-situ cell on this equipment. The samples were heated at a rate of 6°C/min. Diffraction patterns were recorded within a 2θ range of 25–50° continuously since the most intense diffraction peaks of Fe, FeO, Fe3O4 and Fe2O3 phases are located in this 2θ range. The scanning rate was 2°/min. The samples were examined with transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in Talos™ 200a equipment (FEI, USA). Samples were crushed and suspended in ethanol under ultrasonic vibration and finally dispersed on a holey carbon film on a copper grid. MES measurements were carried out in an MR-351 constant-acceleration Mössbauer spectrometer (FAST, Germany) drive with a triangular reference signal at room temperature. The radioactive source was 25-mCi57Co in a Pd matrix. Data analysis was performed using a nonlinear least-square fitting routine that modeled the spectra as a combination of singlets, quadruple doublets, and magnetic sextets based on a Lorentzian lineshape profile. The components were identified based on their isomer shift (IS), quadruple splitting (QS), and magnetic hyperfine fields (Hhf). Magnetic hyperfine fields were calibrated with the 330kOe field of α-Fe at the room temperature. The IR spectra were recorded with a Vertex 70 FTIR spectrophotometer (Bruker, Germany). Powdered samples were diluted with KBr and pressed into translucent disks at room temperature. All spectra were taken in the wave number range of 4000–400cm−1 at a resolution of 4cm−1. LRS was obtained on LabRAM HR800 (Horiba Jobinyvon, France) using CCD as the detector and an air cooled frequency doubled Nd: Yag laser (λ=532nm) as the ray source. XPS was recorded with a VG MultiLab 2000 system (Thermo Electron Corporation, USA) at a base pressure of 1×10−9 mbar. Samples were excited with monochromatized Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV). The analyzer was operated in a constant-pass-energy mode (20eV). The C1s peak of adventitious carbon (284.6eV) was used as a reference for estimating the binding energy. The binding energies were given with an accuracy of ±0.1eV. The reduction of iron oxides over catalyst surface in hydrogen was conducted in an in-situ pretreatment chamber on this equipment. The samples were heated to 300°C at a rate of 10°C/min, hold at 300°C for different times (2h, 5h, 10h and 25h) and then transferred to UHV chamber for XPS analysis. H2-TPR studies were carried out with Autochem II 2920 equipment (Micromeritics, USA). A sample of 40mg of catalyst was loaded into a U-type quartz tube reactor and ramped from room temperature to 800°C in 10% H2/90% Ar with the heating rate of 10°C/min and the flow rate of 50ml/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to monitor the variation of the outlet gas concentration. Isopropyl alcohol gel (−88°C) was used to remove water formed during the reduction. 2.3 FTS performance evaluations The FTS performances of the catalysts were tested in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with inner diameter of 12mm. 3g of catalyst (40–60mesh) was loaded into the isothermal region of the reactor. The remaining volume of the reactor tube was filled with quartz granules. All the catalysts were activated with pure H2 at 300°C, 0.10MPa, and 2000h−1 for 25h. The reaction conditions were maintained at 260°C, 1.5MPa, 2000h−1, and H2/CO=2.0. A detailed description of the reactor and the product analysis system has been provided elsewhere [18]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of catalysts Table 1 gives the BET surface area, average pore size, and alkali/Fe atomic ratios of catalysts. Taking into account the experimental error, BET surface areas of all these catalysts are almost identical except for LiFeSi and NaFeSi catalysts, which exhibit slightly lower surface areas. It indicates that alkali metals have no apparent influence on the textural properties of catalysts. In addition, the particle size of the unprompted and promoted catalysts falls in range of 11.2–11.7nm. It indicates that alkali metals also have no obvious effect on the size of iron oxide particles. However, the alkali/Fe atomic ratio on surface is much larger than that in the bulk of samples. It increases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis from the analysis of XPS and ICP. These imply that alkali promoters largely concentrate on the catalyst surface and the enrichment increases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. 3.2 Interaction between alkalis and FeOx in catalysts Fig. 1 a illustrates Raman spectra of catalysts as prepared. The spectrum of the FeSi catalyst consists of characteristic bands of the FeO bond for α-Fe2O3 located at 217, 244, 283, 392, 497 and 597cm−1 [19,20]. It suggests that α-Fe2O3 is the main phase in catalysts as prepared. With the modification of alkali metals, an additional new peak at around 650cm−1 appears. The possible origins of this new peak are the disorder-induced activation of the IR-active mode present at the same frequency [21] or the presence of alkali ions replacing the iron [19,21]. More importantly, these characteristic bands of FeO bonds are blue-shifted with the addition of alkalis. In addition, the results of FT-IR characterization further confirm the fact that the vibration of FeO bonds shifts to higher frequency with modification of alkalis (See Fig. S1 in the Supporting information). The occurrence of blue-shift in the vibration of FeO bonds indicates that the FeO bond in Fe2O3 phase is strengthened with the modification of alkalis. XPS was used to probe the Fe and O electronic structures in catalysts, since the variation in the strength of chemical bonds have specific relevance to electronic properties of bonding atoms. It is known that electrons in the outer Fe3p core level are more sensitive to the variation of electronic structures. Hence, the Fe3p XPS spectra were used to further probe the changes in electronic structure of Fe species in catalysts. The XPS spectra of Fe3p and O1s are shown in Fig. 2 . Comparing with the FeSi catalyst, the binding energy of Fe3p obviously shifts to lower value to different degrees with modification of alkalis (Fig. 2a). A similar trend of the O1s binding energy is observed in Fig. 2b. The shift in the binding energy in core-level is caused by the variation of the electron density around the central atom [22]. In terms of the screening by valence electrons, the greater the electron density, the lower the electron binding energy is. Thus, the XPS characterization results indicate that the electron density around both Fe and O atoms increases with the modification of alkalis. Alkalis, such as potassium, are assumed to donate electron to iron surface as evidenced by the lowering of the work function of iron [23,24]. In these studies, metallic alkalis are doped on the iron surface. However, alkalis were added to the catalyst precursor by impregnation with alkali nitrates in the present research. Alkali oxides instead of metallic alkalis are formed and enriched on the catalyst surface during calcination. Since the alkali ions reach noble gas electronic structure by losing outermost shell s electron, it is difficult to imagine how electron can further transfer from alkali cations to iron surface. Paál et al. [25] suggested that the composite Fe-O-K layer is the actual surface phase of working catalysts instead of bulk K2O. As discussed above, the surface alkali/Fe atomic ratios are higher than those in bulk for all the catalysts. Therefore, a composite Fe-O-alkali layer probably forms on the alkali promoted catalyst surface, indicating that the Fe-O units are surrounded by alkali ion species. It is known that the electron density of the central atom is greatly influenced by the electronegativity of the atoms surrounded. The lower the electronegativity of the adjacent atoms (groups), the higher the electron density of the central atom is due to partial electron transfer [26]. It is reasonable that the electron density of Fe-O species increase and the binding energy of both Fe3p and O1s decrease because the electronegativities of alkalis are much lower than that of iron. This would result in an electron-rich state of Fe-O species and strengthen the FeO bond in catalysts. These results of XPS further confirm that the FeO bond in iron oxides is strengthened with modification of alkalis, which is consistent with results obtained in the Raman and IR characterizations. 3.3 Reduction behaviors of catalysts 3.3.1 Temperature programmed reduction behaviors of catalysts with in situ XRD The reduction behaviors of catalysts were investigated using H2-TPR (Fig. 3 ). The amounts of H2 consumed during different reduction stages are listed in Table S1 (See in the Supporting information) The profile of the FeSi catalyst exhibits a sharp lower-temperature reduction peak and broad higher-temperature reduction peaks. The lower-temperature peak is corresponding to the first step reduction of hematite to magnetite, because the H2 consumption of this peak is in good agreement with the theoretical value (0.17molH2/mol Fe). The broadened reduction peaks could be deconvolved into two peaks (peaks II and III) using Gaussian and Lorentz fittings. These peaks respond to the subsequent reductions of Fe3O4 to FeO and FeO to α-Fe, respectively. This is verified by the H2 consumptions (0.35mol H2/mol Fe for the peak II and 0.94mol H2/mol Fe for the peak III), which are close to the theoretical values (0.33molH2/mol Fe for Fe3O4 to FeO and 1.0molH2/mol Fe for FeO to α-Fe). These reduction peaks shift towards higher temperatures with incorporating alkali promoters. However, the maxima of these reduction peaks are dependent on alkalis. LiFeSi catalyst shows the highest reduction temperature for the first step reduction. The subsequent reduction of Fe3O4 and FeO are largely retarded to high temperatures by lithium promotion. Moreover, the total H2 consumption of 1.37molH2/mol Fe is lower than the theoretical H2 consumption of hematite to metallic iron (1.5molH2/mol Fe). It indicates that lithium also decreases the reduction degree of the catalyst. With the incorporation of sodium, the first reduction peak has the secondary highest temperature among these catalysts. However, the subsequent reductions of iron oxides are less influenced by sodium. The total H2 consumption is also lower than the theoretical value. Potassium, rubidium and cesium promoted catalysts have gradually decreased temperatures in the first step reduction of hematite. However, the subsequent reductions become separated at high temperatures. That is, there are overlapped peaks in temperature range of 400–600°C, which are hardly influenced by potassium, rubidium and cesium. The reduction peak at above 600°C gradually shifts to higher temperatures with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. Moreover, the total H2 consumption slightly increases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. In situ XRD measurements were carried out to study the phase transformations of iron oxides during TPR process. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns for the unprompted and alkali promoted catalysts. The peaks at 33 and 35° are the characteristics of α-Fe2O3. With increasing reduction temperature, three peaks at 29°, 32.5° and 42° are developed in 2θ range of 25–50°, which are the characteristics of Fe3O4. With further increasing temperature, the XRD patterns evolve into two peaks at 35° and 41°, which are the characteristics of FeO. At the much higher temperature, a new peak at 44° appears, which is the characteristics of α-Fe. The emerging temperatures of these oxydic or metallic iron phases are listed in Table 1. For all the catalysts, the reduction of iron oxides undergoes a consecutive phase transformation process, viz. Fe2O3 →Fe3O4 →FeO→α-Fe. The temperature of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 is ca. 370°C for FeSi catalyst. With the addition of alkalis, this temperature shifts to high values. For different alkali promoted catalysts, it decreases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. The temperature of Fe3O4 to FeO is ca. 570°C for FeSi catalyst. This temperature is nearly identical in LiFeSi and NaFeSi catalysts while it largely decreases in KFeSi, RbFeSi and CsFeSi catalysts, 520, 540 and 520°C, respectively. Similarly, the transformation of FeO to metallic Fe occurs at ca. 630°C over FeSi, LiFeSi and NaFeSi catalysts while it occurs at much lower temperatures (570–580°C) over KFeSi, RbFeSi and CsFeSi catalysts. It is obvious that alkalis inhibit the first step reduction of Fe2O3. However, the inhibitive effect decreases with increasing atomic number of alkalis. That is, lithium has the strongest inhibitive effect on the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Researchers usually ascribe this inhibitive effect to the strong alkali-FeOx interaction. But the intrinsic interaction mechanism is unclear. In the present study, FT-IR, Raman and XPS results have proven that the FeO bonds are strengthened by alkali promotion. The strengthened FeO bonds would become difficult to cleave and result in higher reduction temperatures during the reduction. Besides, there are evidences that the bulk diffusion of oxygen has an important influence on the reduction of iron oxides [18,27]. If the bulk diffusion of lattice oxygen is retarded, the reduction of iron oxides would become difficult. Alkali elements have strong affinity with oxygen. The alkali compositions in bulk of catalysts could have a strong influence on the removal of oxygen in iron oxides. XPS results indicate that alkalis tend to enrich on the surface of as-prepared catalysts. The enrichment increases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. In other words, lithium and sodium have relatively lower surface concentrations in catalysts but higher bulk concentrations. However, potassium, rubidium and cesium have higher surface concentrations and lower bulk concentrations in catalysts. Therefore, lithium interacts with more bulk iron species and shows the highest temperatures for all reduction steps of iron oxides. Sodium also interacts with more bulk iron species, but the bulk sodium concentration is lower than that of lithium. Hence, NaFeSi shows the secondary highest temperature for Fe2O3 reduction. There are gradually decreased bulk potassium, rubidium and cesium concentrations in catalysts. KFeSi, RbFeSi and CsFeSi show stepwise decreased reduction temperatures for Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. In summary, the inhibitive effect of alkalis on the first step reduction also has a close relationship with the bulk concentrations of alkalis in as-prepared catalysts. For reductions in high temperatures, the effects of alkalis become complicated. Lithium inhibits the reduction of iron oxides to metallic iron, which is ascribed to the strong interaction between lithium and iron in the bulk of LiFeSi catalyst. Sodium nearly has no influence on the high temperature iron phase transformations. For potassium, rubidium and cesium, promoters show two opposite effects on the reduction of iron oxides at high temperatures. On one hand, potassium, rubidium and cesium decrease the emergence temperatures of metallic iron. On the other hand, they inhibit the complete reduction of parts of iron oxides at temperatures above 600°C. As we know, most of potassium, rubidium and cesium concentrate on the surface of catalysts. The enrichment on surface would lead to two kinds of distinct iron species in catalysts. One kind of iron species exists on the surface or the outer layer of iron particles, which have a direct interaction with alkali promoters. The others are the bulk iron species, which have a weak interaction with alkalis. Because alkalis strengthen the FeO bonds, it is easy to understand that surface iron species directly contacting with alkalis become difficult to be reduced and the reduction of these iron species gradually shifts to higher temperatures with further enrichment of alkalis with higher atomic numbers. However, it is interesting and difficult to understand that the reduction of some iron species becomes easy. If these iron species have no or weak interactions with alkalis, the transformation of these iron oxides to metals should at least have the same temperatures as those in FeSi catalyst. It should be noted that all these catalysts contain 5% silica in order to maintain a relatively stable activity and selectivity. Possibly, alkalis counteract the strong interaction between iron and silica. Then, some iron species without an interaction with alkalis become easy to reduce in TPR. However, the counteracting effect cannot interpret the reduction behaviors of lithium and sodium promoted catalysts. They should also have lower transformation temperatures to metallic iron than FeSi catalyst. The abnormal reduction behaviors of potassium, rubidium and cesium promoted catalysts can only be explained by the larger alkali concentration differences between surface and bulk of catalysts. As we know, alkalis have strong affinity to oxygen. Probably, the high affinity of surface alkalis to oxygen attracts the oxygen species in the bulk of catalysts and makes ease of the reduction of iron oxides in inner particles of catalyst. 3.3.2 Isothermal reduction behaviors of catalysts using in situ XPS In situ XPS was used to study the reduction of iron oxides over catalyst surfaces. An isothermal reduction process was applied for the reduction in H2 at 300°C. After a period of the reduction (2, 5, 10 and 25h), the catalyst samples were transferred to analysis chamber to collect XPS spectra. XPS is a surface sensitive technique, which can detect the outer layer (limited to less than 1–2nm for kinetic energies in the range of 15–1000eV) of samples. Therefore, the variations of XPS spectra of catalysts in H2 reflect the valence change of surface iron species during reduction. Fig. 5 shows all the Fe2p XPS spectra of catalysts during the isothermal reduction. After hydrogen reduction for 2h (Fig. 5a), the Fe 2p3/2 peaks appear at around 711.2eV, accompanied with a shoulder peak at around 709.3eV, which are attributed to the Fe3+ in Fe2O3 and Fe2+ in FeOx, respectively [28]. The Fe 2p3/2 peaks of Fe3+ and Fe2+ become broad and weak in intensity, whereas the characteristic Fe 2p peaks of α-Fe (Fe 2p1/2 at 720.3eV and Fe 2p3/2 at 707.1eV) emerge and become increased in intensity with prolonging the reduction time (shown in Fig. 5b–d), indicating iron oxides in catalysts is reduced from Fe2O3 to FeOx and then to α-Fe. The addition of Li, Na and Rb inhibits the reduction of FeOx to α-Fe, whereas the incorporation of potassium accelerates the transformation of FeOx to α-Fe during the initial period (<10h) of the reduction step. For the long time reduction (25h), all the alkali promoters decrease the reduction extent of iron oxides relative to FeSi catalyst. Among them, potassium promoted catalyst shows the weakest inhibiting effect (Fig. 5d). For the Li and Na promoted catalysts, the FeO bonds of iron oxide species over catalyst surface are strengthened and become difficult to cleave due to the alkali-FeOx interactions. As a result, the reduction of iron oxide species to metal iron is retarded with the incorporation of Li and Na promoters. Simultaneously, the bulk concentrations of Li and Na are higher than that of K, Rb and Cs, as mentioned in foregoing sections. The higher affinity of bulk Li and Na to oxygen may attract the oxygen species on the surface of catalysts and would also make the reduction of iron oxides over the catalyst surface become more difficult. For the KFeSi catalyst, there may be two kinds of distinct iron species existed over the catalyst surface. One kind of iron oxide species has weak or no interactions both with K and SiO2, because the K-FeOx and SiO2-FeOx interactions would be disturbed by K-SiO2 interaction in KFeSi catalyst. The K-SiO2 interaction have been reported in the previous literatures [7]. This kind of iron oxide species could be easily reduced to metal iron for their weak interaction with both K and SiO2. Thus, the addition of potassium will facilitate the initial reduction of surface iron oxide species to metal iron. The others are underlying and/or neighboring the alkalis and directly interact with alkali promoters. This kind of surface iron oxide species is difficult to be reduced, because K-FeOx interactions would strengthen the FeO bonds. Therefore, it is reasonable that the promotion of potassium is unfavourable to the reduction of surface iron oxide species for 25h long time reduction, although it accelerates the initial reduction of surface iron oxide species. There may be also two kinds of distinct iron species existed over the RbFeSi catalyst surface. However, there should be more iron oxide species interacted directly with alkali promoters over RbFeSi catalyst than that over KFeSi, because the surface concentrations of Rb are higher that of K. As a result, the addition of Rb retards the reduction of surface iron oxide species to metal iron. 3.3.3 Iron phase compositions of catalyst after reduction Mössbauer spectroscopy was used to analyze the iron phase composition of catalysts after reduction in H2 at 300°C for 25h. The Mössbauer spectra are shown in Fig. 6 a, while the iron phase compositions of samples obtained by fitting the Mössbauer spectra are listed in Table 2 . The Mössbauer spectra of all catalysts contain three sets of sextets. The sextets with Hhf of 484±2kOe and 455±2kOe can be attributed to the tetrahedral and octahedral sites of Fe3O4. The former represents the Fe3+ at the tetrahedral site (A site), and the latter contains the Fe3+ and Fe2+ at octahedral site (B site) in Fe3O4 [7]. The other sextet with Hhf of 333±1kOe corresponds to the α-Fe [29]. As shown in Table 2, the predominant phase of FeSi catalyst is α-Fe (62.2%) and the remainder is Fe3O4 after activation treatments. With the addition of lithium and sodium, the content of α-Fe decreases to about 40%, while the amount of α-Fe species is kept at about 50% in potassium, rubidium and cesium promoted catalysts. These results indicate that the incorporation of alkalis decreases the reduction degree of catalysts, while the reduction degree increases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis for different alkali promoted catalysts. These are consistent with the results obtained in TPR, in situ XRD and XPS characterizations. 3.4 Phase compositions of catalysts after FTS reaction Fig. 6b shows the Mössbauer spectra of catalysts after FTS reaction nearly for 145h. They can also be fitted with three sextets with different hyperfine parameters. As summarized in Table 2, the used catalysts are composed of Fe3O4 and έ-Fe2.2C with different ratios. It is found that the iron carbide content in lithium and sodium promoted catalysts slightly increases, while it further increases to about 30% in potassium, rubidium and cesium promoted catalysts compared to that of FeSi catalyst. The results reveal that the addition of alkalis can improve the carbonization of catalysts during the reaction process, and the improvement increases with the increasing the atomic number of alkalis. The Raman spectra of catalysts after FTS reaction are displayed in Fig. 1b. It can be seen that only a very broad with a low signal-to-noise ratios band at 1600cm−1 is found in the spectrum of FeSi catalyst. In contrast, the spectra of alkali-promoted catalysts exist a sharp peak with high signal-to-noise ratios at 1600cm−1 and a shoulder at 1379cm−1. As reported in literatures [30,31], the band at around 1600cm−1 could be attributed to an ideal graphitic lattice vibration mode, while the band at around 1370cm−1 is induced by disorders in the graphitic lattice. Therefore, the Raman results of used catalysts apparently suggest that the incorporation of alkalis would lead to the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface in different extent during the FTS reaction process. 3.5 FTS performance The FTS performances of catalysts were measured under reaction conditions of 260°C, 1.5MPa, H2/CO=2.0, and GHSV=2000h−1. The activity, stability and product selectivity were evaluated within a period of about 145h steady state runs. 3.5.1 Activity and stability The FTS reaction results of catalysts are presented in Table 3 and Fig. 7 . Under a fixed set of process conditions, the CO conversion is used as a measure of FTS activity and the variation of CO conversion with time on stream (TOS) can be used as an indicator of catalyst stability. The CO conversion of FeSi catalyst is about 53% and remains almost unchanged during the whole reaction period. LiFeSi catalyst shows the lowest CO conversion. A slight deactivation with increasing TOS takes place on this catalyst. NaFeSi catalyst shows higher CO conversion than LiFeSi, but its activity is still lower than that of FeSi catalyst. A decrease of CO conversion with increasing TOS is also observed over NaFeSi catalyst. In contrast, the initial CO conversions are largely increased with the promotion of potassium, rubidium and cesium, which show an increased order of KFeSi<CsFeSi<RbFeSi. In despite of the difference in initial CO conversions, the CO conversions quickly decrease to about 60% for these catalysts. Evidently, lithium and sodium suppress the FTS activity while potassium, rubidium and cesium improve the FTS activity compared with FeSi catalyst. Besides, alkali promoted catalysts all show obvious deactivation behaviors during the FTS reactions. According to the characterization results mentioned in foregoing sections, alkalis significantly modify the physical and chemical properties of iron based catalysts. Raman spectra of catalysts after FTS reaction indicate that alkalis improve the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. It is generally accepted that iron carbides are necessary to show FTS activity while the formation of polymeric (amorphous) and graphitic carbon would lead to catalyst deactivation [32,33]. Machocki [34] investigated the performance of metallic Fe-Co catalysts for FTS and found that carbonaceous deposition caused the rapid decrease in activation of catalysts. In the work of Ott et al. [35] similar behaviors were also observed over the carbon deposited Fe-Ru catalysts for FTS. Therefore, the deactivation of alkali promoted catalysts could be ascribed to the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface during the FTS reaction process. For different alkalis promoted catalysts, more carbonaceous depositions form on the surface of heavier alkalis (K, Rb and Cs) promoted catalysts than that of lighter alkalis (Li and Na) promoted catalysts. Because heavier alkalis have higher surface concentration and stronger basity than lighter alkalis, which would facilitate the CO adsorption and in turn enhance the formation of carbon depositions. As a result, heavier alkalis promoted catalysts show a much quicker deactivation than lighter alkalis promoted catalysts. Furthermore, it is widely accepted that the metallic iron or iron carbides are active [36,37] while iron oxides are inactive for FTS reactions [36]. Poor or incomplete reductions would lead to a lower CO conversion. Yang et al. [38] and Suo et al. [39] also found that the degree of reduction decreased with adding silica to iron-based catalyst, which led to a lower FTS activity. The MES results of activated catalysts show that the incorporation of alkalis decreases the reduction degree of catalysts, while the reduction degree increases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis for different alkali promoted catalysts. However, as demonstrated by Mössbauer results of used catalysts, the catalysts were transformed into ε’-Fe2.2C and Fe3O4 phases after exposure to the reaction environment. The iron carbide content in lithium and sodium promoted catalysts slightly increases, while it further increases to about 30% in potassium, rubidium and cesium promoted catalysts compared to that of FeSi catalyst. Therefore, the different reduction or carburization extents may explain the variation of the FTS activity over different alkali promoted catalysts. Both the reduction degree after activation and the carburization extent after FTS reaction increase with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. This correlates well with the activity of the different alkali promoted catalysts. However, FeSi catalyst has the highest reduction degree among all these catalysts, while it does not show the highest initial activity. Although FeSi catalyst contains the lowest iron carbide content after FTS reaction, it does not exhibit the lowest activity at the end of the reaction among all catalysts. These exceptions imply that the content of active phase is not the sole factor to influence the activity of these catalysts. The CO adsorption and dissociation on iron surfaces are also crucial factors in determining the catalyst activity [6]. Alkalis (especially for potassium) are reported to facilitate either molecular or dissociative CO adsorption on the catalyst surface [40]. The effects of alkalis on the CO adsorption are probably due to their basicities or electron donation abilities. Lots of papers reported that alkali can reduce the surface work function of transition metals and improve the CO dissociation on these metals [40–42]. It is mainly ascribed to the strong basicity of alkali with quite low ionization potentials, which can easily donate outer-shell electron to transition metals [43]. In foregoing sections, XPS characterization results imply that the addition of alkalis leads to an electron enrichment of iron species. The electron rich state of iron species will facilitate either molecular or dissociative CO adsorption on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the surface concentration of alkalis increases with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. Alkalis concentrated on the catalyst surface tightly interact with surface iron species and are more effective on facilitating the adsorption and dissociation of CO than that in the bulk of catalysts. Therefore, the effectiveness of alkalis on improving CO adsorption would increase with increasing the atomic number due to their surface concentration increasing in the same trend. As a result, low activity obtained over lithium and sodium promoted catalysts could ascribed to their low reduction degrees and relatively weak promotions on CO adsorption. In contrast, potassium, rubidium and cesium promoted catalysts have enough active phases and high surface effective alkali to promote CO adsorption, which in turn show higher activities in FTS reactions. 3.5.2 Product selectivity Detailed hydrocarbon distributions at the beginning and the end of the reaction (24 and 144h) are given in Table 3. It is clear that FeSi catalyst has the highest methane selectivity among all catalysts and alkalis apparently decrease the methane selectivity. In detail, the methane selectivity decreases with increasing atomic number of alkalis, reaches a minimum at KFeSi catalyst and then increases slightly. The selectivities of heavier hydrocarbons show an opposite trend to methane with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. Besides, olefin/paraffin ratios show an increased tendency with the atomic number of alkalis. The effect of alkali on the hydrocarbon distribution observed in the present study is generally in agreement with the results obtained in several earlier studies [9,44]. The FTS product distribution can be influenced by many factors. It is reported that the CO conversion level can affect the product selectivity [45]. In fact, the CO conversion level changes the H2/CO ratio in the reactor. A high H2/CO ratio can facilitate the production of methane. However, Table 3 indicates that there is no direct correlation of the CO conversion level and the exit H2/CO ratio with the hydrocarbon selectivity. For example, LiFeSi has the lowest CO conversion and lowest exit H2/CO ratio among all catalysts, while it does not show the lowest selectivity of methane. Hence, the H2/CO ratio or CO conversion level has a negligible influence on the product selectivity in this study. The effect of alkalis on the selectivity of products is mainly due to their effect on the strength of CO and H2 chemisorptions [7]. Promotion of alkalis increases the strength of CO adsorption and suppresses that of H2. This results in a high CO/H concentration ratio on the catalyst surface and consequently leads to a low hydrogenation activity. Low hydrogenation activity would suppress the hydrogenation of surface CHX species and secondary hydrogenation of olefin. As a result, low selectivity of methane, high selectivity of heavier hydrocarbons and olefin are obtained over alkali promoted catalysts. The difference in product selectivity of different alkali promoted catalysts could be ascribed to their different surface distribution of alkalis. Alkalis concentrated on the surface of catalyst tightly interact with surface iron sites, which are neighboring or surrounding alkalis. Consequently, alkalis concentrated on the catalyst surface would be more effective on tuning the strength of CO and H2 chemisorptions and in turn more effective on shifting the distribution of products to heavier hydrocarbons and olefin. As mentioned in forgoing section, the surface concentration of alkali increases with the increasing atomic number of alkalis. Therefore, the heavier alkalis (K, Rb and Cs) are more effective on shifting the distribution of products to heavier hydrocarbons and olefins than lighter alkalis (Li and Na). 4 Conclusions In this study, the alkali-FeOx interaction, roles of alkalis (Li, Na, K, Rb and Cs) on the reduction behaviors and catalytic performance of iron-based FTS catalysts were studied. Alkalis had strong interactions with iron species in catalysts. In as-prepared catalysts, the alkali-FeOx interaction strengthened FeO bonds, which in turn inhibited the reduction of catalysts. Due to differences in distribution, Li and Na strongly inhibited the reduction. In contrast, K, Rb and Cs slightly inhibited the initial reduction but improved the transformations of iron oxides to FeO and metallic iron. In addition, alkalis facilitated the carbonization of catalysts, and the improvement increased with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. Alkalis also improved the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface during the FTS reaction process. In FTS reactions, Li and Na decreased the activity while K, Rb and Cs largely increased the activity of iron catalysts. Alkalis led to an apparent deactivation of catalysts, which was ascribed to the carbon deposition on the alkali promoted catalysts. The selectivities to methane exhibited a parabola-like trend with increasing the atomic number of alkalis and reached a minimum at KFeSi catalyst. However, an opposite tendency was observed for the selectivities of heavier hydrocarbons. coredata.dc:description: Alkalis (Li, Na, K, Rb and Cs) promoted Fe/SiO2 catalysts were used to investigate the influences of alkalis on the alkali-FeOx interaction, reduction behavior, and catalytic performance of iron-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts. Laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Mössbauer effect spectroscopy (MES), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (in situ XPS) and in situ X-ray diffraction (in situ XRD) were employed to characterize the catalysts. It was found that alkalis had strong interactions with iron species in catalysts. In as-prepared catalysts, the FeO bonds are strengthened by alkalis, which consequently influenced the reduction of catalysts. Li and Na strongly restrained the reduction of all iron oxides in catalysts. K, Rb and Cs inhibited the initial reduction step (reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4), while improved the reduction of iron oxides to FeO and metallic iron. Besides, alkalis facilitated the carbonization of catalysts and the improvement increased with increasing the atomic number of alkalis. In FTS reactions, Li and Na decreased the FTS activity while K, Rb and Cs largely increased the FTS activity of iron catalysts. The selectivities to methane and alkane were decreased while those to olefin and heavier hydrocarbons were increased by alkalis.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of alkalis on iron-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts: Alkali-FeOx interaction, reduction, and catalytic performance
